stem: The hepatology nurse is reviewing the 6-month follow-up records for two clients with Hepatitis B. Based on the documentation in the Serology Evolution History, match the findings to the correct clinical outcome.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 32-year-old male diagnosed with acute Hep B six months ago. Today he reports feeling 'back to 100%'. Liver enzymes have normalized. 
Patient B: 40-year-old female diagnosed with acute Hep B six months ago. She reports ongoing fatigue and RUQ discomfort. Her liver enzymes remain slightly elevated.

rows.text: HBsAg (Surface Antigen) remains positive after 6 months.
HBsAg (Surface Antigen) becomes negative and Anti-HBs becomes positive.
IgM anti-HBc is positive while HBsAg is positive.
Anti-HBs (Surface Antibody) is positive but HBsAg is negative.

rationale.correct: Acute infection (c1) is marked by the presence of both the antigen and the 'immediate' IgM antibody (r3). If the Antigen (HBsAg) stays positive past 6 months (r1), the patient has failed to clear the virus and is a Chronic Carrier (c3). If the Antigen disappears and the Antibody (Anti-HBs) appears (r2, r4), the infection is Resolved, and the patient is immune (c2).
clinicalPearls: The '6-month mark' is the legal definition of chronicity in Hepatitis B.
Total Anti-HBc stays positive for life, regardless of whether you resolved it or became chronic.
Chronic carriers are at high risk for cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a chronic carrier is 'immune' because they have had the virus for so long.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If they still have the Antigen (HBsAg), they are definitely NOT immune; they are still contagious.

mnemonic.title: Positive Antigen = Positive for Virus
mnemonic.expansion: If they still have the 'Piece' (Antigen) at 6 months, they still have the Problem (Chronic).
